article-doc.publication: The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition

p.link: The U.S. and other powers said it would be virtually impossible to reach a nuclear deal with Iran by Monday’s deadline and favor extending talks.
Tunisian politician Beji Caid Essebsi was widely expected to defeat 21 other candidates in the country’s first democratic presidential election.
Bahrain’s Shiite opposition blasted government claims that over half of registered voters took part in elections.
Putin said he doesn’t seek to be Russia’s president for life but doesn’t rule out seeking another term in 2018.
A suicide bombing struck a volleyball tournament in eastern Afghanistan, killing 45 to 60 spectators.
Doctors at a Boston hospital discussed the risks of a tool used in hysterectomies in 2011 but continued to use morcellators for two more years.
Protests continued through the weekend in Ferguson, Mo., as a grand jury was set to reconvene in the police shooting case.
The wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 left a separatist area of Ukraine, bound for the Netherlands.
A 12-year-old Cleveland boy who was shot by police when he allegedly reached for a BB gun died Sunday morning; The University of Virginia suspended fraternal activities amid a sex-assault probe.
Died: Marion Barry, 78, controversial four-term mayor of Washington, D.C.
